U of L in top 2 for 5-star Terrance Ferguson

Steve Jones, swjones1@courier-journal.com 12:31 a.m. EST December 2, 2014
Buy Photo

Prime Prep of Dallas' Terrance Ferguson (5) on the basketball court at Seneca High School in Louisville, Kentucky. December 1, 2014(Photo: John Sommers II, John Sommers II/Special to the Courier-Journal)Buy Photo

3 CONNECT 24 TWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE

Five-star junior wing player Terrance Ferguson said the University of Louisville trails only Baylor on his recruiting list and will take an unofficial visit to U of L on Tuesday.

    Ferguson, a skilled, athletic guard from Dallas' Prime Prep school, scored 14 points all in the second half in a 61-50 loss on Monday night during the Bluegrass Showcase at Seneca High School with U of L coach Rick Pitino and two assistants watching.

    Afterward, he and his mother said they'll tour U of L's campus on Tuesday, then attend the Cardinals' game against Ohio State at the KFC Yum! Center. U of L is also expected to have power forward Thon Maker arguably the top player in the 2016 class visit for that game, too.

    "I'm looking forward to seeing the system they play in, the coaching type and I'm looking for the fan base also, because that's going to be a big part in what I'm looking for," said Ferguson, who's ranked No. 8 in the 2016 class by Rivals.com and No. 10 by Scout.com. " (Fan support) gets me going."

    U of L:

    Ready for stern Ohio State test

    Sullivan: Pitino pries open UK can of worms

    Ferguson said U of L, which offered him a scholarship several months ago, has a current top three, in order, of Baylor, Louisville and Arizona.

    "Baylor, I've been watching them for the past three years, and I like the coaching system," Ferguson said. They have great coaches. Louisville, obviously they have great coaches as well and a long history behind the school name. And Arizona, their fan base is crazy, and I'd love to play down there also."

    Ferguson said he was excited to see Pitino at his game on Monday night.

    U of L:NCAA nears Shaqquan Aaron decision

    AND: Russell unsure how U of L fans will greet him

    "It was great. As a little kid, looking up to these big coaches and having them come watch you play now, it's a blessing.

    He continued: "(Pitino) has a long record behind his name, so it's always great to play behind Coach Pitino," he said. "The program, period, is a great program. It would be a blessing to play with them.

    Ferguson does not have a scholarship offer from the University of Kentucky but said it would "be a blessing" to have one, and the Wildcats would automatically be in his top five if they did.
